Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: The Games and Learning Digital Distribution Platform: Increasing Access with Web-Based Content
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will create the first trusted source where parents and teachers can easily find, buy and adopt high-quality digital content for their children. Games, e-books and other digital learning tools show significant potential for improving lives. Children in low-income families (43% of all U.S. children) spend more screen time than their higher income counterparts, and their teachers are twice as likely to report improved student achievement from using educational technology. Despite increasing supply and demand related to digital learning tools, great content is buried within current distribution platforms and educators do not find choices mapped to their needs. As a result, 30 million U.S. children living in low-income families lack access to relevant content, 55% of parents and 80% of teachers cannot find what they are looking for and content producers face significant challenges to sustainability. By offering a broad selection of high-quality, cross-platform digital learning content via a platform optimized for adoption by educators who serve low-income communities, this project will achieve significant advances in access, impact and revenue. Using feedback from a Phase I prototype, this project will scale to reach the 3 million U.S. teachers who currently use digital learning products in the classroom and the 30 million U.S. families who use digital learning products at home. A revenue share with digital learning providers will establish a dedicated, sustainable channel within the $20 billion global e-learning market.


This project is a systemic solution to digital learning distribution that meets teachers and parents where they are, but fundamentally disrupts their current expectations for effective content. As the first project to connect web-based, evidence-based digital learning tools with educators at scale, there are significant risks. The technical requirements for creating a one-stop shop for web-based learning tools are evolving daily from how to support the development of more high-quality HTML5 content, to how to best sell and deliver access codes for cross-platform/cross-device delivery, to how to ensure ease of download and adoption by educators despite limited bandwidth. Development in HTML5 offers an emerging opportunity to more efficiently target a global audience without maintaining multiple versions of the same application and improve educational connections between home and school. However, many digital learning developers lack the resources to convert high-quality content to HTML5 without the support of a sustainable distribution platform. This project will create a web-based e-commerce application optimized for delivery of cross-platform content, a searchable inventory of high-quality digital learning products mapped to educational standards and a data/feedback loop designed to improve long-term satisfaction, sustainability and efficacy. Phase I R&D efforts will use surveys, virtual focus groups and educator journals/interviews to test the technical and commercial feasibility of both the supply side and demand side of a new platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Games and Learning Digital Distribution Platform: Increasing Access with Web-Based Content

Small Business Innovation Research Program Phase I Outcomes Report

Overview

Games and Learning advances digital media that improves children's lives by developing a trusted source where parents and teachers can easily find, buy and adopt high-quality digital content. Through a 2019 Small Business Innovation Research Phase I grant from the National Science Foundation, Games and Learning partnered with leading content creators to develop a prototype distribution platform and collect insights from educators within the First Book network. First Book makes educational resources more affordable and accessible to its member network of more than 450,000 registered educators who serve children in need. The objectives for this grant period were to determine technical and commercial feasibility of this new platform by investigating the following questions: 1) What are the key levers related to growing and maintaining supply of web-based product offerings; 2) What strategies are most effective for supporting product discovery and purchase by educators and 3) What types of support are most likely to increase successful adoption with students who will benefit the most from high-quality digital learning materials.

The Games and Learning team combines decades of research and development experience, subject matter expertise and unique industry relationships to solve the problem of effective digital learning distribution. We work with a consortium of digital learning providers, many of whom are grantees of the Small Business Innovation Research program, to help guide our commercialization strategy. With partners at First Book, we reach a growing audience of educators who serve low-income students. Results from Phase I research benefit from comparative analysis with prior First Book/Games and Learning studies on how educators use digital learning resources with their students.

The team employed both quantitative and qualitative research methods to understand how educators use and perceive the new Games and Learning platform, and to determine what enhancements or features would improve feasibility and efficacy. Our iterative prototype development process started by surveying more than 500 educators in the First Book network on general needs and priorities, to inform which product attributes and platform features are most critical to successful adoption. Based on the their feedback, the team created the first iteration of product onboarding, evaluation and page design. The team then developed initial page designs to display product information and solicited feedback via virtual focus groups. Page designs were improved and then re-tested, with a second round of focus groups and a series of user journals.  Throughout the research and development process, the team also conducted more than 30 customer interviews with educators and administrators to inform plans for commercialization. 

Intellectual Merit

Research shows that digital games, e-books and educational apps offer high levels of engagement, built-in assessment, personalized content and the ability to bridge home and school.Games and Learning is creating the first platform to successfully solve the significant problem of effective digital learning distribution, achieving measurable impact while leveraging lessons learned from previous efforts. By offering a broad selection of high-quality, cross-platform digital learning content via a platform optimized for adoption by educators who serve low-income communities, the new platform shows potential to achieve significant advances in access, impact and revenue. We see a timely opportunity to lead a new wave of web-based content development that will unlock a share of traditionally native iOS/Android revenues and serve a growing, global audience of customers. Phase I research confirmed that educators place high value in the Games and Learning Product Review Scorecard, desire a "one stop shop" with a variety of curated digital learning products and rely on discounted pricing available through the First Book network.

Broader/Commercial Impact

All children should benefit from high-quality digital content that improves their learning and development. Despite increasing supply and demand related to digital learning tools, 30 million U.S. children living in low-income families lack access to relevant content, 55% of parents and 80% of teachers cannot find what they are looking for and content producers face significant challenges to sustainability. The new Games and Learning distribution platform offers products that best serve children, with accessible choices at lower prices for those in need. It reduces the friction that teachers face when finding, buying and implementing digital learning content by offering high-quality, easily searchable choices that are platform-agnostic. The platform will scale from its current channel within First Book's Marketplace to become a sustainable, research-driven consumer platform for digital learning content distribution. We aim to reach the 3 million U.S. teachers who currently use digital learning products in the classroom and the 30 million U.S. families who use digital learning products at home, while ensuring that all students have access to the highest quality resources.
